content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
─────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of:
• Stone Furnace at Position(x=0.0, y=0.0) paired with burner inserters and output chests. This network processes raw ores into plates.
• Stone Furnace at Position(x=5.0, y=0.0) similarly equipped.
(Note: Although additional iron plate extraction was performed from the furnace at (0.0, 0.0), the network’s structure remains unchanged.)

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of:
• A burner‐mining drill (with its associated mining components) connected to a wooden chest and interlinked by transport belts for collecting iron ore.
  
### Automation Research Lab
Consists of:
• A laboratory receiving automation‐science-pack inputs, supported by a network of small electric poles to maintain power.

### Water Supply System for Power Generation with Updated Steam Engine Placement
Consists of:
• A Boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) with connection points at Position(x=8.5, y=18.5) and Position(x=8.5, y=22.5); its fluid box holds 200 units of water.
• An Offshore Pump at Position(x=0.5, y=30.5).
• Pre‐existing Steam Engines at Positions:
  – (1.5, 13.5)
  – (13.5, 14.5)
  – (19.5, 14.5)
  – (13.5, 17.5)
  – (17.5, 20.5)
  – (11.5, 20.5)
  – (22.5, 18.5)
• An additional Steam Engine was crafted and placed at Position(x=4.5, y=23.5) (Steps 409/414) to enhance network connectivity; however, repeated attempts to connect it via pipes to the Boiler have failed.
• Multiple PipeGroups are deployed to route fluids. Recently, 8 new Pipe units were crafted for connection purposes, but integration with the newly placed engine remains unresolved.

ERROR TIPS
────────────
• Pipe Connection Failures
 – Verify that the candidate connection areas (for both the Boiler and Steam Engine) are clear of obstructions and within a buildable zone.
 – Confirm that sufficient pipe inventory is available before initiating connection commands (e.g. “Required number – 8, Available – 0” indicates a shortage).

• Repositioning and Entity Placement Issues
 – Undefined function errors (e.g. “shift_entity is not defined”) indicate missing utility function definitions; ensure all helper functions for repositioning are properly defined and used.
 – Attribute errors during rotation (such as a string being used where an object is expected) require verifying the data type of the entity parameter before calling transformation methods.
 – Placement failures due to terrain obstacles (such as water or other blocking entities) necessitate pre-checking the target area’s buildability.

• Crafting and Resource Shortages
 – Insufficient resource errors (for instance, being unable to insert coal into a furnace or failing to craft pipes due to missing iron-plate sub-ingredients) highlight the need to ensure production chains and inventory levels are adequate before executing craft commands.
 – Monitor and maintain the supply of critical intermediate items (like iron plates) to support dependent crafting operations.

• General Connection Issues
 – When connections between entities (such as from the Boiler to a Steam Engine) repeatedly fail, re-assess both the positional alignment and surrounding environment for potential blockages, and adjust entity placement accordingly.
